importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication, signaling that China's new export controls on rare-earth metals were announced recently and are expected to take effect in December 2025.
The effective date of the new export restrictions on rare-earth metals and related equipment, marking when foreign companies will need to obtain special approvals from China.
The expected date of the Trump-Xi meeting during the APEC summit in South Korea, which frames the strategic timing of China’s export controls as a pre-meeting diplomatic maneuver.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period between the announcement of new controls and their implementation gives the US and other nations time to prepare for supply chain disruptions and negotiate with China.

keyTakeAways: China has expanded its export controls on rare-earth metals, restricting 12 of the 17 known rare-earth elements, including adding five new metals (holmium, erbium, thulium, europium, ytterbium) to the list.
The restrictions apply to both raw rare-earth metals and specialized equipment used to refine them, requiring foreign companies to obtain special approvals and disclose intended use.
China cites national security concerns, citing direct or indirect transfers of controlled rare-earth materials to military or sensitive applications as a justification.
The US is the largest importer of Chinese rare-earth products, with 70% of its rare-earth imports originating from China between 2020 and 2023, making it highly vulnerable to these controls.
Rare-earth metals are essential for critical technologies such as electric vehicles, lithium-ion batteries, AI semiconductors, fighter jets (e.g., F-35), submarines, and missile guidance systems.
China controls at least 60% of global rare-earth mining and 90% of processing capacity, giving it significant strategic leverage in global supply chains and geopolitical negotiations.
The move is interpreted by analysts as a signaling tactic ahead of a high-stakes meeting between US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping at the APEC summit in South Korea.
China has committed to bilateral and multilateral export control dialogue mechanisms to promote compliant trade and secure global supply chain stability.
The US has previously restricted China’s access to semiconductors, creating a mutual dependency that makes decoupling difficult and underscores the interdependence of the two economies.

summaryOfNewsArticle: China has expanded its export controls on rare-earth metals, restricting 12 out of 17 known rare-earth elements—adding five new metals (holmium, erbium, thulium, europium, ytterbium) to its prior list of seven—effective December 1, 2025. The restrictions target both raw materials and refining equipment, requiring foreign companies to obtain special approvals and disclose intended uses. China justifies the move on national security grounds, citing concerns over transfers of controlled materials to military or sensitive applications. The announcement comes just weeks before a high-stakes meeting between US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping during the APEC summit in South Korea, positioning China’s actions as a strategic signal to strengthen its negotiating leverage. The US, the largest importer of Chinese rare-earth products, faces significant supply disruptions affecting defense systems such as F-35 jets, submarines, and missiles, as well as civilian technologies like electric vehicles and AI semiconductors. Analysts interpret the move as a deliberate pre-meeting maneuver, highlighting China’s dominance in the global rare-earth supply chain and the deep interdependence of the US and Chinese economies. The restrictions also underscore the vulnerability of US industrial and defense capabilities, while China emphasizes cooperation through multilateral export control dialogues to ensure global supply chain stability.
